statement.tex: \text{Find the Cartesian equation of the line which} \\ \text{passes through the point }(-2, 4, 5)\text{ and} \\ \text{is parallel to the line } \dfrac{x+3}{3}=\dfrac{4-y}{5}=\dfrac{z+8}{6}.

step.context: \textbf{Another general question} \\ L:\dfrac{x+3}{3}=\dfrac{4-y}{5}=\dfrac{z+8}{6} \\ \text{Does $(3, -6, 0)$ satisfy the equation } \\ \text{of the above line?}
step.reason: L:\dfrac{x+3}{3}=\dfrac{4-y}{5}=\dfrac{z+8}{6} \\ \text{Substituting $(3, -6, 0)$ in the above line results} \\ \text{in }\dfrac{3+3}{3}=\dfrac{4+6}{5}=\dfrac{0+8}{6} \\ \implies 2 = 2 = \dfrac{4}{3}. \\ \text{Therefore, $(3, -6, 0)$ does not satisfy the} \\ \text{equation of the line $L$.}

\text{For a line to be parallel to } \\ \dfrac{x+3}{3}=\dfrac{4-y}{5}=\dfrac{z+8}{6}, \\ \text{it must have direction ratios 3, 5 and 6}. \\ \text{And for a line to pass through }(-2, 4, 5), \\ \text{the point must satisfy the equation of the line.} \\ \text{Both the conditions are satisfied by} \\ \bf\dfrac{x-1}{3}=\dfrac{y-9}{5}=\dfrac{z-11}{6}\qquad(1).\\ \text{It is possible however that you expected} \\ \text{a different looking equation. For e.g. } \\ \bf\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y-4}{5}=\dfrac{z-5}{6}\qquad(2), \\ \text{This is also correct as it satisfies both conditions.} \\ \text{Note that adding 3 to each term in equation (1)} \\ \text{would result in (2), hence both are equivalent.}
